questions.text: Abortion is the expulsion of fetus weighing _____.
questions.solution:
According to WHO, abortion is defined as pregnancy termination or loss before 20 weeks of gestation or with a fetus weighing <500 g.

Some common causes of spontaneous abortion are:

  • Chromosomal abnormalities 
  • Luteal phase defects
  • Diabetes mellitus and thyroid disorders
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
  • Maternal infections
  • Alcohol and cigarette smoking

questions.text: A patient presented with vaginal bleeding following 6 weeks of amenorrhoea. Her UPT was positive. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of first-trimester abortion which is most commonly caused by chromosomal abnormalities.

Autosomal trisomies are the most common (50%) genetic abnormality overall. Of these, the most common trisomy involved in abortions is trisomy 16. Turner syndrome (monosomy X) is the single most common chromosomal abnormality in miscarriages.

Causes of spontaneous abortion are:

  • Genetic - 
    • Numerical chromosomal abnormalities
    • Chromosomal rearrangements
    • Mendelian etiology
  • Endocrine -
    • Luteal phase defects
    • Thyroid abnormalities
    • Diabetes mellitus
  • Anatomical - 
    • Cervical incompetence
    • Congenital uterine malformations
    • Uterine fibroid
    • Uterine synechiae
  • Infectious (TORCH infections)
  • Immunological -
    • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
    • Autoimmunity
  • Maternal illness - 
    • Cyanotic heart diseases
    • Hemoglobinopathies
  • Environmental -
    • Radiation exposure
    • Alcohol
    • Cigarette smoking

questions.text: A patient presented with a spontaneous abortion at 7 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is the least likely chromosomal abnormality that can lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
The least likely chromosomal abnormality involved in first-trimester abortions is trisomy 1.

The most common chromosomal abnormality in first trimester abortions is trisomy. The common trisomies are:

  • Edwards syndrome (Trisomy 18)
  • Down syndrome (Trisomy 21)
  • Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13)
  • Trisomies 16 and 22 

Turner syndrome (Monosomy X) is the single most frequent chromosomal abnormality. It usually results in abortion.

questions.text: A woman with 6 weeks of amenorrhea had a positive urine pregnancy test. The following finding was seen on transabdominal USG. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given USG image shows an empty gestational sac which is seen in missed abortion before 12 weeks. At this gestational age,  the entire ovum is covered by the chorionic villi giving rise to the empty gestational sac.

If this condition occurs beyond 12 weeks of gestation, a dead fetus is seen on USG. This is not preceded by any warning signs and the fetus is not expelled outside spontaneously.

questions.text: Recurrent miscarriage is the loss of:
questions.solution:
Recurrent miscarriage is defined as ≥3 consecutive pregnancy losses at ≤ 20 weeks or with a fetal weight <500 g.

It can be of 2 types:

  • Primary recurrent miscarriage where there are multiple losses in a woman who has never delivered a liveborn
  • Secondary recurrent miscarriage where multiple pregnancy losses occur in a patient who has had a prior live birth

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not usually cause recurrent miscarriages?
questions.solution:
Infections do not usually cause recurrent miscarriages. 

Common causes of recurrent miscarriage:

  • Parental chromosomal abnormalities
  • Anatomical factors - 
    • Uterine synechiae or Asherman syndrome
    • Uterine leiomyomas
    • Congenital genital tract anomalies
  • Immunological factors -
    • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
  • Endocrine factors - 
    • Luteal phase defect
    • Polycystic ovarian syndrome

questions.text:
A primigravida had a spontaneous abortion at 18 weeks. On examination, the fetus was morphologically normal. Further investigations were performed upon the patient's insistence and the results are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
  • Antibody against β-2 glycoprotein - Negative
  • Lupus anticoagulant - Positive
  • Anti-cardiolipin antibody - Positive
  • aPTT - Prolonged
  • Protein C - Normal
  • Hysterocervicography - Normal
questions.solution:
The given lab findings are suggestive of anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome(APLS). 

Criteria for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:

Clinical criteria -

  • Obstetric
    • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
    • One or more deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks
    • Severe pre-eclampsia necessitating delivery before 34 weeks
  • Vascular
    • One or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ

Laboratory criteria -

  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant
  • Presence of IgG or IgM anti-cardiolipin antibodies
  • Presence of IgG or IgM anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies

At least one clinical and one laboratory criteria is needed for the diagnosis.

Non-specific tests for lupus anticoagulant are increased aPTT, Kaolin clotting time, and dilute Russell viper venom time.

questions.text: A woman comes to the casualty at 18 weeks of gestation with complaints of vaginal bleeding. She has a history of two early pregnancy losses. USG reveals the absence of fetal cardiac activity. Which of the following investigations need not be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent abortions, and extensive infection workup is not done.

Even though recurrent abortions are defined as ≥3 pregnancy losses, investigations must be done after 2 consecutive losses.

Diagnostic evaluation of recurrent pregnancy loss based on etiology is given as follows:

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a ​history of recurrent abortions is now diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome. What would be the best mode of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
The best mode of treatment for a pregnant woman with antiphospholipid syndrome(APS) is aspirin and heparin.

APS is a prothrombotic disorder (autoantibody-mediated thrombophilia) affecting both arterial and venous systems.

Patients present with recurrent pregnancy loss due to thrombosis of uteroplacental vessels, poor placental perfusion, and prevention of normal decidual changes after zygote implantation. They may also present with preterm delivery, pre-eclampsia, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), and fetal death.

Criteria for APS include:

  1. at least one otherwise unexplained fetal death at or beyond 10 weeks;
  2. at least one preterm birth before 34 weeks gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, placental insufficiency; or
  3. at least three unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks. 

Aspirin (60-80mg daily) with heparin (5000-10,000 U subcutaneously every 12h) is the most effective therapy for APS. Treating APS with only aspirin (option A) is not recommended as heparin is crucial in preventing thrombus formation at the decidual-thrombotic interface, Corticosteroids (option C, D) should not be used in primary APS (without an associated connective tissue disorder) but are indicated in patients with pre-existing systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and APS (secondary APS).

questions.text: A G3A3 patient was admitted to the hospital with catastrophic APLS following a spontaneous abortion. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is a rapidly progressive thromboembolic disorder
At least 2 organ systems should be involved to make a diagnosis
Infections can act as a trigger
IVIG can be used for treatment

questions.solution:
Catastrophic antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (CAPS) is a complication of APLA syndrome, in which ≥3 organ systems are involved. It is also known as Asherson syndrome.

It is seen in both primary and secondary APLA syndrome. Triggering factors include infections, trauma, and obstetric causes. IVIG can be used in CAPS when the first-line therapies with aspirin and heparin have failed.

Note: Asherman syndrome is an acquired condition characterised by formation of intrauterine adhesions or synechiae.

questions.text: Which of the following features can be seen in a patient with cervical incompetence?

choices.text: Repeated third trimester painless cervical dilatation
Bleeding per vaginum in the first trimester

questions.solution:
Cervical incompetence or insufficiency is characterized by repeated mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation. Escape of amniotic fluid followed by painless expulsion of products of conception can also be seen.

Risk factors for cervical incompetence:

  • Congenital uterine anomalies
  • Acquired -
    • Dilatation and currettage 
    • Dilatation and evacuation
    • Vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix
    • Amputation of cervix 
  • Multiple gestations
  • Prior preterm birth

questions.text:
Which of the following increase the risk of developing cervical incompetence?
  1. In-utero exposure to DES
  2. Twin pregnancy
  3. History of MTP with Mifepristone
  4. Genital tract infections
  5. Bicornuate uterus
questions.solution:
In-utero exposure to DES, twin pregnancy, and bicornuate uterus increase the risk of cervical incompetence.

Offsprings born to pregnant mothers who were treated with diethylstilbestrol may develop cervical hypoplasia and malformation. They may also present with cervical incompetence during their 2nd trimester.

Cervical incompetence can be seen following MTP with surgical methods and not with medical methods.

The retentive power of the internal os may be compromised by anatomical abnormalities like bicornuate uterus and overdistended uterus due to twin gestations.

Risk factors for cervical incompetence:

  • Congenital uterine anomalies
  • Acquired -
    • Dilatation and currettage 
    • Induced abortion by dilatation and evacuation
    • Vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix
    • Amputation of cervix 
  • Multiple gestations
  • Prior preterm birth

questions.text: The transvaginal ultrasound of a pregnant woman is given below. What are the cutoff values of the parameters marked A and B for a diagnosis of cervical incompetence?
questions.solution: In the given image, the parameter marked A is funnelling of the internal os and the parameter marked B is cervical length. Funnelling of internal os and cervical length <25 mm are diagnostic of cervical incompetence on transvaginal ultrasound.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive UPT. Her past obstetric history was significant for 2 mid-trimester abortions. On USG, cervical length was 20 mm and no bulging membranes were seen.  What is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cervical incompetence. It can be managed with prophylactic cervical cerclage done between 12 and 14 weeks of gestation.

Rescue or emergency cerclage is done anytime within 24 weeks of gestation. It should only be done when there is bulging of membranes through the dilated cervix. 

Investigations for cervical incompetence:

  • In interconceptional period - 
    • Passage of number 6 - 8 Hegar's dilator beyond the internal os without resistance or pain
    • Funnel-shaped shadow in premenstrual hysterocervicography
  • During pregnancy -
    • Per speculum examination showing cervical dilatation with herniation of membranes
    • USG revealing cervical length <2.5 cm and funnelling of internal os >1 cm

questions.text: A patient with cervical insufficiency is posted for McDonald's procedure.  Which of the following is not a contraindication for this surgery?
questions.solution:
McDonald's procedure is a type of cervical cerclage. It can be done up to 24 weeks of gestation.

Contraindications to cervical cerclage are: 

  • Absolute
    • >24 weeks of gestation 
    • Active labour
    • Active vaginal bleeding
    • Abruptio placenta
    • Premature rupture of membranes
    • Chorioamnionitis
    • Severe uterine irritability
    • Fetal death or defect
  • Relative
    • Prolapsed membranes
    • Vaginal spotting

questions.text: A woman with cervical incompetence is posted for prophylactic McDonald's cerclage. Which of the following statements is false about this procedure?

choices.text: Removal of stitch must be done by 37th week
A mersilene tape is tied around the cervix
Done at the level of internal os

questions.solution:
In McDonald's cerclage, a nonabsorbable suture, such as Mersilene, is placed as a purse-string suture as high as possible at the level of the internal os, positioned at the junction where the rugose vaginal epithelium transitions to the smooth vaginal portion of the cervix, below the bladder.

Another cerclage procedure is Modified Shirodker's technique. In this, a non-absorbable (mersilene) tape is passed subcutaneously through a transverse anterior incision and is tied posteriorly.

Removal of cerclage should be done by 37 weeks of gestation. It can be removed earlier in case of preterm labour.

Complications of cervical cerclage:

  • Slipping of suture
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Abortion or preterm labour
  • Cervical laceration or scarring

Many patients do not have the classic history that indicates prophylactic cerclage in the late first or early second trimester. Therefore, many cerclage procedures are performed emergently rather than prophylactically

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient came for medical termination of pregnancy. From whom will you obtain consent for the procedure?
questions.solution:
Only the patient's consent is required for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) and her male partner's consent is not required.

Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 yrs or if the patient is mentally ill.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A patient with contraceptive failure requires MTP at 5 weeks of gestation. You plan to use a medical method of abortion in her case. Which of the following is not a contraindication for this?
questions.solution:
Chronic diabetes mellitus is not a contraindication to medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) with medical methods.

Contraindications to medical methods of abortion are:

  • Women with in situ intrauterine device
  • Severe anemia, coagulopathy, or anticoagulant use 
  • Long term corticosteroid therapy 
  • Severe liver, renal, pulmonary, or cardiovascular disease
  • Inherited porphyria
  • Uncontrolled hypertension

Contraindications to surgical methods of abortion are:

  • Suction and evacuation - uterine size >10 weeks
  • Intrauterine instillation of hypertonic solution - cardiovascular or renal lesion and severe anaemia

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant rape victim was posted for a suction and evacuation procedure. This procedure can be done up to _____ of gestation.
questions.solution:
Suction and evacuation can be done up to 12 weeks of gestation. It is a method of termination of pregnancy in the first-trimester.

The various methods of termination of pregnancy are: 

Timing Medical methods Surgical methods

1st trimester

(up to 12 weeks)
  • Mifepristone
  • Mifepristone and Misoprostol
  • Methotrexate and Misoprostol
  • Tamoxifen and Misoprostol
  • Menstrual regulation
  • Vacuum aspiration (MVA/EVA)
  • Suction evacuation and/or curettage
  • Dilatation and evacuation -
    • Rapid method
    • Slow method 

2nd trimester

(13 - 20 weeks)
  • Misoprostol
  • Dinoprostone
  • Carboprost
  • Dilatation and evacuation
  • Intrauterine instillation of hyperosmotic solutions
  • Oxytocin infusion
  • Hysterotomy

questions.text: You have performed MTP on a multigravida at 10 weeks of gestation.  As a part of post-op advice, you must prescribe her a prophylactic antibiotic. Which of the following drugs would you prefer?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is the preferred drug for post-abortal antibiotic prophylaxis in this case. Oral doxycycline 100 mg is given 1 hour before surgical evacuation. 200 mg is given after the procedure is complete.

The best method of MTP at 7-12 weeks is by suction and evacuation. Following this procedure, antibiotic prophylaxis is given with doxycycline.

questions.text: You are about to administer misoprostol to a woman who requires MTP in the 8th week of her pregnancy. What is the dose of this drug when given by the mucosal route, according to WHO guidelines?
questions.solution:
Misoprostol is given at a dose of 800 mcg by mucosal route for MTP.

Mucosal misoprostol administration has increased efficacy and minimizes gastrointestinal side effects. Hence, it is preferred over oral administration. 

WHO guidelines for medical management in induced abortion for <12 weeks of gestation:

  • Combined regimen (recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal, or sublingual misoprostol
  • Misoprostol only regimen (alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually, or buccally

Related Pearl: Uses of Misoprostol

INDICATIONS PRIMARY DOSE OF MISOPROSTOL REMARKS

MEDICAL TERMINATION OF PREGNANCY

 

Combined Regimen(recommended):
Upto 12 weeks of gestation-800mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually.

Beyond 12 weeks of gestation-400mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually every 3 hours


Misoprostol only regimen:
Upto 12 weeks-800mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually

Beyond 12 weeks-400mcg vaginally, bucally or sublingually every 3 hours

Ideally used 1-2 days after 200mg of Mifepristone in the combined regimen.


The mucosal route of administration is preferred over the oral route of administration.


These doses also apply for incomplete and missed abortion.

SURGICAL ABORTION

 Cervical preparation: 400mcg vaginally/ sublingually

Another method: Oral Mifepristone 200mg 24-48 hours before the procedure

 
PPH Prophylaxis

single dose for PPH secondary prevention (approx >350ml blood loss)

PPH treatment 800 mcg sublingually single dose

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the methods of MTP?

choices.text: Pain is more in medical methods of abortion
Incomplete abortion is more common in medical methods
Bleeding is prolonged in surgical methods
Failure rate is low in surgical methods of abortion

questions.solution:
Bleeding is prolonged and unpredictable in medical methods of abortion.

Comparison of drawbacks of medical and surgical methods of MTP:

Factor Medical methods Surgical methods
Invasiveness Usually not invasive Invasive
Pain More Less
Vaginal bleeding Prolonged, unpredictable Light, predictable
Incomplete abortion More common Uncommon
Failure rate 2-5% 1%
Severe bleeding 0.1% 0.1%
Infection rate Low Low
Anesthesia Usually not given Always given
Time involved  Multiple visits for follow-up  Usually one visit
No follow-ups required

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought in a drowsy state from a PHC with complaints of fever, severe lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge. Her mother revealed that she had had an unsafe abortion a week ago. On examination, her abdomen was distended, BP was 80/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm, and RR was 36 breaths/ minute. Which of the following is not a causative agent of her present condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of toxic shock syndrome (TSS) following septic abortion. Escherichia coli can be detected in septic abortion, but it is not a causative agent for TSS.

Organisms causing toxic shock syndrome in septic abortion:

  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Clostridium perfringens
  • Clostridium sordellii

Clinical features of septic abortion:

  • Fever with chills and rigors
  • Abdominal or chest pain
  • Diarrhoea and vomiting
  • Renal angle tenderness
  • Offensive purulent vaginal discharge.

Clinical grading of septic abortion:

  • Grade I - infection localized in the uterus
  • Grade II - infection spreads to parametrium, tubes, ovaries, or pelvic peritoneum
  • Grade III - generalized peritonitis, endotoxic shock, jaundice, or acute renal failure

Empirical antibiotic therapy in septic abortion is started for the broadest microbial coverage. Piperacillin-tazobactam or carbapenem and clindamycin are given intravenously. Antibiotics can be changed once culture sensitivity reports are available.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for stillbirth?

choices.text: Illicit drug abuse by the mother

questions.solution:
An untreated seizure disorder in pregnancy is not a risk factor for stillbirth. However, the use of certain anti-epileptic drugs like valproate could lead to the development of neural tube defects in the baby.

Recent studies haven't consistently shown that untreated women with epilepsy face a higher risk, though it's hard to rule out entirely because those who manage without medication usually have milder symptoms. Recent research found that birth defects were more common in children of women who used anticonvulsants. 

Risk factors for stillbirth are:

  • Advanced maternal age
  • African-American race
  • Smoking
  • Illicit drug use
  • Maternal medical diseases - overt diabetes or chronic hypertension
  • Assisted reproductive technology
  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Previous adverse pregnancy outcomes - prior preterm birth or IUGR

 

Note: Stillbirth rates appear to be slightly increased in pregnancies conceived via assisted reproductive technology.

questions.text: A young female has history of a spontaneous abortion. She has had amenorrhea since then. Her FSH now is 6 mIU/ml. Which of the following can be a cause for her amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
The development of uterine synechiae is the most likely cause of amenorrhoea in the given clinical scenario.

Certain types of spontaneous abortions such as inevitable, incomplete and missed abortions might require medical assistance for complete removal of products of conception including procedures such as dilatation and curettage.

Vigorous uterine curettage in early pregnancy damages the basal layer of endometrium leading to scarring and adhesions in the uterus that interferes with normal endometrial growth and shedding.This causes the clinical feature of secondary amenorrhea as seen in this patient.

This intrauterine adhesions are known as uterine synechiae or Asherman syndrome.

As there is no defect in the hypothalamo-pituitary-ovarian axis in the asherman syndrome, the levels of FSH remain within the normal range of 4 - 25 IU/L as seen in this patient.

In the case of Pituitary dysfunction (option A) the FSH levels are usually decreased.

In ovarian dysfunction (option B) the negative feedback of ovarian hormones (estrogen) on pitutary and hypothalamus is lost. Hence, the levels of FSH is increased (≥ 25 IU).

Asherman syndrome is characterised by a spectrum of intra uterine scarring including thin adhesions, dense bands, or complete obliteration of the uterine cavity. It occurs due to endometrial damage following vigorous curettage, usually in miscarriage, or elective abortion. Damage may also occur from other uterine surgeries such as myomectomy or cesarean delivery or from an infection related to an intrauterine device.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients may present  with amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea or recurrent pregnancy loss due to inadequate placentation.

Asherman syndrome shows multiple filling defects on hysterosalpingography (HSG) or saline-infusion sonography. Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic lysis of adhesions is the preferred surgical treatment for the syndrome.
